Text_Numeracy: Last spring, I developed a painful rash on the back of my neck. When I visited the doctor, I suspected it was shingles, because the pain and rash were similar to my earlier bout with shingles. The rash continued to spread, so I went to a walk-in clinic to get medical help. The Physician Assistant looked at the rash and said she thought it might be shingles, too. She checked for other symptoms. She asked me if I had been sick recently. I said I had a slight breathing issue from allergies and had taken medicine for that, but otherwise I felt fine. She looked for photos of rashes on the internet to compare with mine to get a better idea of what she was seeing. At this moment, I mentioned that in the past when I had shingles, I had some mild respiratory issues, along with a slight fever, at the onset. Her final diagnosis was insect bite dermatitis. She prescribed some ointment for the rash and told me to take some over-the-counter pain medicine for the pain. After a day or two, the rash began to subside and the pain lessened significantly in a few days.

Text_Numeracy: One experience that stands out for me was when I took the initiative to research the various prescription medications I was on. It was a pivotal moment that highlighted the importance of being knowledgeable about one’s own health.

Text_TrustPhys: I actually don't have a primary care physician, so my views are more generalized about doctors. While I often feel confident in making health decisions, I find that I may need to seek clarification or additional information when it comes to my medications and overall health management.

Text_Numeracy: I believe that the best way for you to learn about health is to experience it yourself, which is what I've done at every stage in my life. In my early 0s, I went through a period of malaise and fatigue, and it caused me to become physically fit and also aware of what could cause such effects. At 25, I got dr to the even-worse fatigue and muscle cramps I had had before. It turns out I was mildly anemic and needed iron supplements and a better diet. Later in life, I went through a period of emotional strain, and went to a hypnotist for some stress relief. That caused much worse symptoms, but the experience led me to experience meditation and yoga.  From that point onward, I have been as free of stress as possible and am rarely up-tight and generally find my self calm and relaxed in all situations. When my mother went through cancer treatments and had to see doctors and specialists regularly, I accompanied her and learned a lot about the treatments and side-effects and corresponded with other patients online about their experience for support. It prompted me to write a book that she could leave her other family members, so they would know her experience in her words.  Now, I'm learning about the pitfalls of aging,

Text_Numeracy: few months ago my seventeen year old son was sick. His symptoms were a severe sore throat, swollen glands, and fever. I told him to gargle with salt water, drink tea with honey, take ibprofen for the fever, and suck on throat lozengers.
Text_Anxiety: Im having a possibly serious illness, and me being afraid of doctors and needles.
Text_TrustPhys: I trust my PCP through the relationship we've built over the past several years. I sometimes distrust just doctors in general because I've had a few bad experiences with random doctors in the past that made me feel like I was being treated as a paycheck rather than for the well-being of my health.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel that I have a good capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information. I carefully listen to everything my doctor says and then ask many questions. I use the internet to research any medical issues I may have.

Text_Numeracy: I had a bowel blockage that showed an X-ray. The doctor said it does not look good and he might cut my stomach open to see what is going on. I asked what happens if he cuts me open and see nothing. He could patch me up and I could still be blocked and back for surgery. So I continued to wait. After nine hours, I eventually pooped okay.
Text_Anxiety: I feel most worried that they might find something wrong with me❣️😳❣️
Text_TrustPhys: Trust her! She cares, listens to concerns, gives the right vaccine etc.  Also a far seperti kakabdsssrsrrdssssssrrrrrrrrrssss. Repeats.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I can obtain and process all my medical information without assistance 99% of the time , I know how to ask for help when I need it, I am very knowledgeable of medical terminology

Text_Numeracy: I gave birth to a healthy baby boy with no complications. I had a successful vaginal delivery. Although it was my third child; so I had previous experience, I still feel it was an impressive physical accomplishment.
Text_Anxiety: I just say waiting for answers for things sometimes its hard to hear that some things are not the results you expect the case may be
Text_TrustPhys: Because I have a tendency to ask a lot of questions I usually do not get straight answers from any CPD. It usually involves him taking a guess as to what he thinks might be wrong or just simply telling me to go for more testing. Would it kill doctors to actually do more testing rather than elderly-causing guesswork?
Text_SubjectiveLit: I definitely feel comfortable with that. I have my doctor, his nurse, and the receptionist to help with paperwork. If I'm not sure of the paperwork that is given to me, I either ask the receptionist, or when I go back into the office and the nurse comes to see if I need anything, I ask her.

Text_Numeracy: I have had health issues related to diabetes and obesity. I also have a family history of high blood pressure. I have made efforts to try to eat a healthy diet and get regular exercise, but struggle with both, sometimes. I try to keep track of the information and follow through with reporting to my MD for her records and accounability.
Text_Anxiety: There is nothing specific that makes me feel anxious or worried when visiting the doctor's office. I feel nothing. I go for my yearly check-up to find out what has changed about my health since my last yearly check-up.
Text_TrustPhys: Like all doctors, she went to school for a long time, so I suppose she has training and experience. She seem nice and friendly, although I suspect she is kind of a ditz. She is not as thorough as I would like. I saw her for a rash once and she didn't even look at the rash; she just said it looked like eczema.
Text_SubjectiveLit: Pretty completely.  The nurse and the doctor explain pretty well so that they will understand.  I ask questions if I am unclear about anything.  I am just glad they are both as friendly and kind.

Text_Numeracy: When I went to the doctor to check my heart. I had a bit of symptom, so I thought I better check it. The doctor makes me an echocardiogram because of my age and the symptoms. Everything was fine.
Text_Anxiety: no reply
Text_TrustPhys: I trust my physician because they are knowledgeable, experienced, and caring towards their patients. They take the time to listen and make sure what is being prescribed is necessary and beneficial.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I have unlimited capacity I can find any information I need and process it just fine.

Text_Numeracy: As a public employee benefits representative, I have worked with many employees or retirees who have a chronic illness. One member in particular I worked with was a 22 year man who had a chronic illness. I was able to assist the member in obtaining medical coverage for treatment.
Text_Anxiety: I don’t feel particularly anxious about anything .I feel happy that I’ve got good healthcare and a doctor that cares for me
Text_TrustPhys: My pain management doctor is center is what I trust . They have helped me and taken care of me for a lot of years . Encourage people to go there . Plus they don't belittle people
Text_SubjectiveLit: I have gained a lot of information throughout my life regarding my own healthcare needs as well as my parents. I am capable of reading and understanding the instructions that the nurse gives me, or the surgeon gives me. If not, I can always ask questions.

Text_Numeracy: The summer before my senior year of high school, I was seriously injured in a car accident. I spent the summer recovering from a combination of a spinal cod injury, a broken back, a broken collar bone, and a femur that was broken into 3 pieces. I was bedridden for most of the summer, had a full back brace, tried to regain the ability to walk in therapy, and had at least 3 surgeries to insert and remove hardware in my leg. I am still aware of a war of medical issues like PT and bad weather affecting my condition since I am a physically active person. I also have knowledge of insurance and billing issues and how to deal with them since I dealt with them throughout my recovery.
Text_Anxiety: My anxiety is caused by my fear of receiving bad news. Each time I visit the doctor, I prepare for the worst possible diagnosis. There is something about doctors that makes me feel anxious. Just seeing the office causes me to worry.
Text_TrustPhys: I trust in the care I receive from my primary care doctor, because he spends time asking me questions and clarifying my answers. He also explains the science behind a proposed treatment plan, and asks me more questions to gain a better understanding of my concerns about treatment options.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel I have the capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information and services needed to make appropriate health decisions. I do this by keeping track of my doctor appointments and asking questions when I am not sure what something means or might indicate.

Text_Numeracy: One experience that stands out to me was when I was researching the interactions of the various prescription medications I was taking. With my frequent visits to different specialists, I realized how important it was to understand how these medications could potentially affect each other and my overall health. I spent hours reading medical literature and consulting pharmacists to ensure I was managing my health appropriately. This experience not only deepened my understanding of pharmacology but also highlighted the importance of being proactive about medication management in the absence of a primary care physician.
Text_Anxiety: I don’t really feel anxiety when I meet doctors, as I approach these visits with a neutral mindset. However, I do find myself worried about the potential changes to my medication regimen or unexpected side effects. It also crosses my mind that not having a primary care physician might complicate my treatment or lead to inconsistencies in my care. Overall, it's more about the uncertainty of how my prescriptions will be managed rather than the interaction itself.
Text_TrustPhys: I don't have a primary care physician, and honestly, my feelings towards doctors in general are mixed. On one hand, I appreciate their knowledge and expertise, particularly in prescribing the medications I need to manage my health. However, I sometimes find it hard to trust them completely because I feel like they often focus on medication rather than looking at the whole picture, like my lifestyle or emotional well-being. I've seen various specialists and therapists, but I still feel a lack of continuity in my care, which makes it difficult to fully trust anyone in the medical field.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I believe I have a moderate capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information and services. While I do take many prescription drugs and frequently visit psychologists, I often find myself feeling overwhelmed by the information presented to me. I can engage in physical activity and have some knowledge of health topics, but I struggle to translate that into making informed health decisions, particularly given my lack of a primary care physician. This gap in my healthcare management can sometimes leave me feeling uncertain about my overall well-being.
